p: In order to improve SRP equity for young women and men within the context of South Africa, we need reliable and valid measures that are grounded in the lived realities of youth who are disproportionately affected by HIV. As such, there is a need to assess the validity and reliability of current metrics used to measure the construct of SRP equity among young South African women and men. In this paper we aimed to explore the gendered properties of a South African adaptation of the original SRPS [ 11], through three objectives including: 1) to describe gender-stratified responses and properties of the SRPS used within the youth-engaged cohort study ‘AYAZAZI’, 2) to examine differential associations between socio-demographic and relationship determinants and SRP equity and, 3) whether SRP equity is independently associated with HIV-risk, for young women and young men. Given the gendered nature of SRP equity, we expected to identify important differences in factors associated with SRP equity by gender.
